person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Conservation and Adaptation of the 18th-Century French Military Hospital in Port Louis for Reuse by the Intercontinental Slavery Museum

description.narrative: Built of local coral stone, basalt blocks, and argamasse, a roofing material consisting of lime mortar, broken clay tiles, and cane sugar, the former military hospital is a rare surviving example of French, Indian, and Malagasy craftsmanship. This project involves the restoration and adaptation of two buildings at the entrance for reuse by the museum.

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Training in the Preservation of Historic Sites in Maritius

description.narrative: Traditional building practices on the island have been on the decline for several years, making it difficult for the government to find craftspeople with the skills necessary to restore historic sites. This project pairs unemployed youth with local craftsmen in a comprehensive effort to restore historic sites and develop a specialized work force with the skills necessary to maintain them in good condition.

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Documentation of the Mid-19th-Century Quarantine Station on Flat Island

description.narrative: The quarantine station served an important role in the indentured labor system that once existed in Mauritius and the region. This project includes conservation of the station and fits within a larger integrated management framework for ensuring the sustainable preservation and development of the island.

title.narrative: Conservation of the 18th-Century Sugar Mill at Bras d'Eau National Park

description.narrative: Established as a working plantation in 1786 and today a national park, Bras d'Eau endures as a reminder of the impacts of human slavery and indentured servitude on the island of Mauritiuss agricultural and industrial development and environmental transformation between the 18th and early 20th centuries. This project involves the documentation and development of a conservation plan for the plantations historic sugar mill.
